Package com.techietag.springaiagent.tools

Class GetCurrentTime

java.lang.Object
com.techietag.springaiagent.tools.GetCurrentTime
@Service public class GetCurrentTime extends Object
Utility tool that returns the current date/time for a given IANA time zone identifier.

This class is exposed as a Spring-managed service and declares a tool method used by Spring AI tooling. The method expects a valid IANA time zone ID (for example "Europe/London", "America/New_York", or "Asia/Kolkata") and returns the current zoned date-time as a string. If an invalid or unknown time zone identifier is provided, the method returns a user-friendly error message instead of throwing an exception.

Usage example: 

 GetCurrentTime tool = applicationContext.getBean(GetCurrentTime.class);
 String nowInLondon = tool.getCurrentTime("Europe/London");

See: java.time.ZoneId for valid IANA zone identifiers and java.time.ZonedDateTime for formatting options if you need a different output format.

  • Method Details

    • getCurrentTime

      @Tool(description="Get the current time for a specified country", name="GetCurrentTimeTool") public String getCurrentTime(String country)
      Returns the current date and time for the specified IANA time zone identifier.
      Parameters:
      country - the IANA time zone identifier (for example "Europe/London"). This parameter is forwarded to java.time.ZoneId.of(...).
      Returns:
      a String representation of the current zoned date-time in the given zone (produced by ZonedDateTime.toString()), or a user-friendly error message if the provided identifier is invalid.

      Error behavior: - If the provided zone id is invalid or not recognized, the method returns the message: "Invalid country/region provided. Please provide a valid time zone identifier.".

      Notes: - The method intentionally returns a String for simplicity when integrating with tool frameworks; callers that need to manipulate the date-time should parse the result into java.time.ZonedDateTime or modify this method to return a ZonedDateTime object instead.
